results.notes:
Fruit body appeared to be somewhat old, and possibly the cap color had faded or darkened with age. Cap color light off-white with slightly darker UV patches. Photos taken in fairly low light, but observable cap color is close to what I observed first-hand.

Basal bulb softish.

Annulus gray.

Reminds me mainly of the lavendula type(s), but also seems soemwhat like porphyria.

Spores measured from two different potions of a print taken on a slide. One sample 7-10 × 7-9.5; the other 8-11 × 8-10.5. Spores globose to subglobose. Size is significantly larger than what is reported for lavendula.

In stand of pine (a 2 or 3 needle variety; not white pine) with some small hardwoods (oak, birch) mixed in.

This specimen sat out for a day before I put it into the dehydrator.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_667/2012_IMG1427
Picture file names: from Clitocybe-odora_raw_1 to Clitocybe-odora_raw_7.

Habitat: former pastures, now light mixed wood, Picea abies, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus ornus, Corylus avellana dominant; moderately inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; colluvial, skeletal, calcareous ground; in haft shade; dry and relatively warm place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 8-9 deg C, elevation 635 m (2.080 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil, under a canopy of Picea abies.

Place: Bovec basin, at the base of Mt. Čukla; east of meadows near Plajer farmhouse, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Clitocybe odora is easy to recognize. Blue-greenish appearance and strong characteristic smell on aniseed are distinctive.

Growing scattered, several fruit bodies present; pileus diameter up to 6 cm, stipe length up to 5 cm; SP whitish-beige.

Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

On old weathered serpentine outcrop in grassland foothills.

Thallus is areolate, yellowish green, K+Y (light), C+O (light, maybe pink), KC+Orange dark. Apothecia small black lecideine. Hymenium hyaline, epihymenium dark, aeruginous (blueish green), K-, with golden crystals, hypothecium dark brown.

I didn’t get anywhere other than Trapelia in the keys tonight, thought it would be an easy one with that chemistry, gotta put kids to bed so I’m posting it for any help before I take another stab.

results.notes:
Growing near Quercus sect. Lobatae, Carya sp. and Acer saccharum.

It was pretty dry when I found these. Young pores dull yellowish brown. Older pores darker brown and bruising brown. Stem pinkish toward the base with off-white basal mycelium. Stem surgace staining brown. Context staining blue. Context in base of stem red. 5% KOH brown on stem, light brown on cap, and light brown on stem context as well as erasing bluing there. NH4OH neutral on stem and context, light brown on cap. 10% FeSO4 brown on cap, gray on stem and neutral on context. Did not taste.

results.notes: I found this on a planted evergreen oak tree trunk in a park, not a tree native to this area. It was the dominant lichen on the trunks of these trees, but I didn’t see it on any other tree species in the immediate vicinity. I don’t get down to the coast that much, but this is the first time I’ve seen Xanthoria parietina in San Luis Obispo County.

results.notes:
On old weathered serpentine outcrop in grassland foothills.

I was surprised to see Niebla here, but maybe I shouldn’t have been. I didn’t collect any, but the cespitose growth form with terminal apothecia and blades lacking secondary branching, this seems to be the right species. The location is 6.5 miles inland from the ocean, which seems to be pretty far for Niebla combeoides, which is common on the Channel Islands and uncommon on the mainland.

Observatory Hill, Victoria, British Columbia, Canada

results.notes:
Growing scattered in tall lawn grass. Fragile. No odor when cut, mild when crushed.

Basidia 4-spored, ~34+9 x 10. Spores 8.5-10.5 × 5-6.5. Cheilocystidia (smooth outline) 20-30 × 10-18, with (typically several) excrescences about 2.5 microns wide and up to 20 microns long. No pleurocystidia, no clamps observed.

Microscopy is pretty good for M. vitilis, but there are two problems: (1) Growth in grass, not in woody debris; (2) The stipe is not “pliant, even tenacious”. In the Collins Guide (Brittish fungi), M. vitilis is called Snapping Bonnet — “with a stiff stipe that snaps audibly when broken”. Not so here.

results.notes: Growing on a lawn under Quercus sect. Quercus. Cercis canadensis and Juniperus virginiana nearby. Surface of stem base bruising dark red before fading to blackish or bluish. Red fuzz at base of stem. Pores bruising blue. Cap dry and slightly velvety. Red pruina on the stem. Stem fairly tough and sturdy. Taste of cap slightly lemony. Cap context light yellow and staining blue. Stem context also bluing. Context at base of stem red. 5% KOH red on cap, yellow and erasing bluing on cap context, reddish brown on stem surface, light brown on pores and red on context at the base of the stem. NH4OH making cap slightly browner, faintly yellow on stem surface, light yellow and erasing bluing on cap context, reddish brown on context in base of stem and neutral on pores. 10% FeSO4 slightly brownish on cap, faintly yellow on stem surface, neutral on cap context and neutral on context in base of stem. Older pores and stems drying to brown. Younger pores drying to yellowish brown.

Habitat: edge of light mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies, Ostrya carpinifolia dominant trees; moderately inclined mountain slope, south aspect; skeletal, colluvial, calcareous ground; quite sunny place; relatively warm and dry place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 555 m (1.820 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, above regional road Bovec – Vršič near Matevž farm house, Trenta 1; East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Lycoperdon excipuliforme is easy to recognize when old by the fact that its characteristically spongy stem remains standing long after all the rest decays and disappears. Fig. 28 shows what remained of the fruitbody after two days of heavy rain (360 mm of rain in less than 48 hours!).

Growing solitary; diameter of the ‘head’ 4.5 cm; stipe 8 cm long and 3 cm in diameter; SP brown, oac638.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1028/2016_DSC6439

Habitat: pasture, slightly inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; colluvial, skeletal, calcareous ground; full sun, dry and relatively warm place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 625 m (2.050 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: moss overgrown stump of a cut down Picea abies in its late phase of disintegration.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča; Na Melu place, near cottage Trenta 2b, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: This mushroom usually appears in older literature as Galerina autumnalis. But extensive DNA study (Gulden and collaborators, 2001) has synonymized that species – along with Galerina oregonensis, Galerina unicolor, and Galerina venenata – with the older, European species first described in the 18th century, Galerina marginata. The mushroom is deadly poisonous (look at English common name).

Growing in a loose group of about 15 pilei; pilei diameter 1.4 – 4.0 cm (measured as it is, not expanded), surface lubricous-waxy; stipe 4.0 – 6.2 cm long, diameter 2.8 – 7.8 mm, hollow, fibrous; SP abundant, rusty-brown, oac713.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

results.notes: Growing on the bottom of a well-decayed fallen beech tree. Pores white and bruising dark brown. Spore print white. Pores becoming slightly browner in small spots with the application of 5% KOH. Margins of the basidiocarp curling toward the center during drying. Did not notice any amyloid or dextrinoid strutctures under the microscope. Spores inamyloid and globose to subglobose. Basidia seemed to be bisterigmate. Some hyphae thick-walled. Did not notice cystidia but they could have been present. Some rhomboid crystals present among the basidia.

results.notes:
On granite boulders. With the naked eye it looks like Lecidea atrobrunea, a fine dark lichen crust mixed with Acarospora, Caloplaca, Aspicilia and other species. At 20x the consistent brown thallus color makes it look like Acarospora. But, micro details put this at Aspicilia, or probably the newer genus Circinaria.

Thallus consists of brown areoles that are flat to slightly convex, dull, tightly oriented but with cracks separating them, K-, C-. Prothallus absent. Apothecia very small, <0.4mm, one per areole, lecanorine, disk black, concave, with crusty pruina or epruinose, rim not or slightly pruinose. Hymenium and hypothecium hyaline, portions are K/I+blue. Epihymenium yellow brown to dark brown, K-. Paraphyses submoniliform to moniliform.

Asci narrowly clavate to clavate, seemed like 8 spored at first but I actually think this is 6 or less spored. Mature asci were uncommon, and I just couldn’t get a clear look (see pics). Spores simple, hyaline, broadly ellipsoid, large:
20.5×12.9, 22.2×13.2, 20.5×11.2, 23.4×15.8µm.

This keys to Aspicilia desertorum, a complex of species with the North American stuff now known as Circinaria arida, as far as I can tell, but I just don’t think it is right for this specimen.

results.notes:
Pluteus pellitus (Pers.) P. Kumm. Pluteaceae, Agaricales.
Local name of this very common and sometimes abundant kind: Плютей белый.
Cap: 5-10cm, whitish, minor brownish-white, smooth, gentle cone up to broadly convex, some sticky in wet weather, sometimes with radial cracks when dry. Flesh is white and fragile; odour is pleasant.
Gills: free, moderately broad up to broad, close, white or cream-white up to pink when very old.
Stalk: 6-12cm long, 1.0-2.0cm thick and enlarged toward base, brownish-white, uneven as somewhat tiny scabers, indistinct fibrous up to fibrous.
Habitat: common kind, small groups or single scattered at the old partially rotten birch stumps or trunks in pine-tree forest with some birches.
Edibility: edible.
June-September.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1014/2016_IMG1548

Habitat: light mixed wood edge, Picea abies, Fagus sylvatica, Larix decidua, Salix eleagnos dominant trees; slightly inclined mountain slope, north aspect; calcareous, colluvial, skeletal ground; in half shade; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 3-5 deg C, elevation 1.005 m (3.400 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: moss covered soil under young Picea abies trees.

Place: Zadnja Trenta valley, Zapodn place, next to the trail to Zapotok waterfalls, somewhat upstream of a small dam on (mostly dry) river Soča bed, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Craterellus lutescens is generally considered as quite rare mushroom. It is in strong decline in many countries of Europe since it is very sensitive to air emissions by traffic and agriculture. It is protected by law in Slovenia. However, in Trenta valley the species is still quite common. It usually appears in large colonies having several tens of fruitbodies.

Growing scattered in a large group of more than 30 fruitbodies; pilei diameter up to 7 cm, stipe up to 10 cm long and 2.1 cm in diameter; smell distinctive, fresh, typical on chanterelles, pleasant; taste mild, pleasant; flesh brittle, fibrous; SP yellowish, oac6.

Uredba o zavarovanih prostoživečih vrstah gliv, Uradni list RS, št. 58/2011 (Regulation of protected wild fungi, Official Gazette of Republic Slovenia, no. 58/2011), (2011).

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
This particular collection is the third observation of this species in the Netherlands! Here’s the distribution of this species in our country: https://www.verspreidingsatlas.nl/0027160

Description:

Pileus: 10-28 × 10-29 mm; cylindrical at first, then conical, eventually expanding with revolute margin; grey, silvery-grey to dark-grey, ochraceous or darker in the centre; very inconspicuous filamentose velum; striate, later sulcate-plicate.

Lamellae: Crowded to normal distance, narrow, free from the stipe; brownish-grey, then grey, eventually black; margins white at first; deliquescent.

Stipe: 63-70 × 2-4 mm; central, flexuous, bent at foot, tapering towards pileus; entirely covered in fine appressed fibrils, denser at the base, no “sock” around the base; white.

Context: Thin, almost nil in pileus; greyish-white, brownish-grey in the cortex of apex and pileus, greyish in the base; hollow.

Microscopy:
- Spores: (Broadly) Ellipsoid, sometimes with more acute apex; fairly thick-walled; granulose interior; central germpore (+/- 2 µm); dark red-brown, near opaque.
- Measurements (1000x; oil-im.; H2O; 1 sd=1,02 µm)
Spores: (9,18) 11,12 (12,24) µm x (6,12) 6,48) (7,14) µm; Qav: 1,72
- Velum: Large, inflated, sausage-shaped, hyaline, slightly encrusted chains of cells.

Smell/Taste: No particular smell, no taste recorded.

Ecology: Solitary or subcespitose, terrestrial or on buried wood, broadleaf forest (Fagus), mesotrophic sandy soil.

results.notes:
Description:

Pileus: 18-33 × 12-14; parabolic-campanulate to convex with small and low umbo to expanded with undulating margin; smooth or rugulose (especially when drier); partially covered with white filamentose velum; deep vinaceous-brown, later paler towards the margin, with white outmost margin due to velum (appendiculate); strongly hygrophanous from centre towards margin, younger specimens stays two-toned longer than older specimen, the former with a leather-brown centre and dark chestnut margin, the latter entirely pale brown.

Lamellae: L: 27-30, l: 3-7; normal distance to subdistant, adnate, ventricose; brown with paler margin; margin finely floccose (60x magn.); hygrophanous.

Stipe: 84-114 × 4-7 mm; central, cylindrical, slightly broadening towards the base, slightly torqued; surface irregular, sericeous, pruinose at apex and velutinose on lower part towards the base because of white basal mycelium, longitudinally striate and grooved at apex; base with white rhizoids; pale vinaceous, paler towards the apex; becomes pale brown after picking.

Context: Brittle, yet firm; thin in pileus, hollow in the stipe; concolourous with or paler than exterior of stipe, brown in cortex of the base and where the lamellae are attached to the stipe.

Smell/Taste: No particular smell nor particular taste, although young specimen’s smell is faintly reminiscent of Tricholoma sulphureum and Lepiota cristata after cross-section.

Microscopy:
- Spores: Oblong, smooth, hyaline; very small apiculus, very small rounded germ pore (+/- 1 µm); reddish-brown in H2O.

- Measurements (1000x oil-im., H2O, 1 sd=1,02 µm)
- 14,28 × 7,14 µm
- 14,28 × 7,14 µm
- 15,30 × 7,14 µm
- 14,28 × 7,14 µm
- 14,28 × 7,14 µm
- 14,28 × 7,14 µm
- 14,28 × 8,16 µm
- 15,30 × 7,14 µm
- 13,26 × 7,14 µm
- 14,28 × 7,14 µm
av. 14,382 × 7,242 µm
stats. (13,26) 14,38 (15,30) µm x (7,14) 7,24 (8,16) µm

- Cheilo- and pleurocystidia: 95 × 15 µm; (narrowly) conical, thick-walled, embedded/”rooted” deeply in lamellar trama, encrusted at the apex.

Ecology: Scattered on forest floor under Fagus, in leaf litter and on bits of wood, humus rich sandy soil; sharing habitat with several other species of Psathyrella, Mycena spp, Tricholoma album, Lepiota cristata.

results.notes:
Christine Fischer, truffle researcher at the Forest Science Center of Catalonia, Spain, leads truffle and mushroom forays in Spain. These truffles were found using trained dogs. Christine identified the truffles and took the photos labeled T mesentericum (posted with her permission) in her laboratory.

Tuber mesentericum Vittadini 1831
Peridium is black, warty with distinctive basal depression, ripening in the autumn, and found growing with deciduous trees in calcareous soils, especially in southern Europe.
This truffle is closely related to and confused with T. aestivum/uncinatum, but distinguished by its basal depression or cavity. The odor is described as tar-like or of iodine, changing to a more pleasant and sweet odor when exposed to air.
Gleba beige to brownish-grey with white marbling by sterile veins.
Asci, with short peduncle, 1-6 spores/ascus, most frequently 3-4 spores/ascus
Spores are yellow-brown, ellipsoid with reticulate ornamentation, and the spore volume/ascus is greater than that of T. aestivum.
from Funghi Ipogei D’Europa
Amer Montecchi & Mario Sarasini
AMB Centro Studi Micologici

https://www.verspreidingsatlas.nl/0073550

Description:

Pileus: 22-40 × 10-12 mm; convex with decurved margin when young to plano-convex with broad, flattened umbo when mature; central velum patch velutinose (20x magn.), concentrically breaking up into smaller squamules towards margin, subsurface radially fibrillose; orangey-brown with ochraceous subsurface, velum darker than subsurface; no discolouration after bruising, although rubescent where animals have eaten.

Lamellae: Numerous, crowded, free from stipe; white at first, becoming orangey-brown (a day after picking) starting on the margin of the pileus; margins white at first, later darker orangey-brown; lamellulae present (l: 3).

Stipe: 24-36 × 6-8,5 mm; central, cylindrical, slightly bulbous base; velum similar to that on the pileus, forming a reddish-brown layer around the base, pulled apart upwards and gradually sparser, forming unconnected bands; incomplete cortina just above halfway of the stipe with squamulose margin; entirely fibrillose subsurface; whitish to pale reddish (appears to be blushing), more orangey at the apex; rubescent where animals have eaten.

Context: Firm, fairly thick in the centre of the pileus, becoming hollow in stipe; white, slightly browner in the stipe, rubescent/orangey where animals have eaten.

Microscopy:
- Spores: Ellipsoid, but ovoid to amygdaliform in side view, very variable in shapes and sizes; smooth, granulose or guttulate inside; double-walled, apiculus prominent and eccentric.
- Measurements (1000x; oil-im.; H2O; 1 sd=1,02 µm; n=12)
- Spore stats.: (5,10) 6,80 (9,18) µm x (4,08) 4,55 (6,12) µm
- Qav: (1,11) 1,50 (2,00)

Ecology: Terrestrial, mixed coniferous woods with Pinus, Picea and more, fairly thick humus and leaf litter layer, meso- to eutrophic sandy soil; sharing habitat with several Clitocybe spp., Lepista nuda, Macrocystidia cucumis, Lepiota cristata, Strobilurus sp. and Baeospora myosura.

Notes: I shared the collage of this collection in an Italian based facebookgroup, called “LEPIOTA e FUNGHI LEPIOTOIDI”, where I added the question: “Is this L. cortinarius or L. ochraceofulva?” The very kind Mario Di Giangregorio shared his thoughts, pictures and prints of descriptions for both species, which were sections from “Flore Mycologique d’Europe – Les Lépiotes – documents mycologiques hors série 3 – Lepiotaceae – Marcel BON – 1993”. I am very grateful for the help offered by the kind Mario!

results.notes: Growing on the cut end of a spruce log on the side of the trail. Basidiocarp rubbery to corky. Fertile surface gray-brown. Cap 7 mm thick where measured and possibly thicker elsewhere. Cystidia brown, encrusted and visible under low magnification. Cystidia not arranged in fascicles. Setae absent. Clamp connections present. Basidiocarp turning black with a drop of 5% KOH. I was only able to find one spore, which measured 13.5 × 4.8 μm. This spore was only slightly above the range for V. abietina in length, but this combined with location (V. abietina is rare in Colorado while V. fimbriata is common) makes V. fimbriata more likely.

results.notes: Group of four on trail near Clear Lake under a Madrone. I took three in which the cap was fully, partially and not separated from the veil. The inrolled margins of the middle form were flattened in the older. Sizes ranged from a stipe length of 13 cm to 7, and cap diameter from 11 to 5 cm. White spore print. Cap smooth and yellowish with large umbo forming with age. Older unfringed even margin lacking striations. Older lacking remnants of veil, middle with veil still partly attached as a sheet like membrane rather than fibrous or wispy. Gills white with a slight tan cast, close and barely attached. Degraded near the stipe in the older. Youngest fully enclosed with veil. Stipe even with tapering base, breaks with a snap but incompletely, appearing fibrous. Stipe appearance variable with age, older smooth with brown to reddish color above the ring zone. No ring or significant remnants visible other than sheathing membrane beneath the colored region. Lower white with yellowish cast and streaks.. Middle with thick single sheathing ring flaring upwards. upper part of stipe white with small white patches something like sparse white scabers. Stimpe beneath ring like older. Tapering base rooted into soil. Mushrooms barely emerged from soil. Radish smell when cut open. Thick, white solid context throughout. No discoloration on youngest on cap or stipe, but drawing a fingernail along the stipe of the middle produced an immediate color change to brown. All photos taken on a cloudy day with external ambient light.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1021/2016_DSC5962

Habitat: in light mixed wood, close to its edge, Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies, Ostrya carpinifolia dominant trees; moderately inclined mountain slope, south aspect; skeletal, colluvial, calcareous ground; mostly in shade; relatively warm and dry place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 555 m (1.820 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, above regional road Bovec- Vršič near Matevž farm house, Trenta 1, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: First I thought I found another Hygrocybe conica which is frequent in Trenta valley. However, genus Hygrocybe and particularly H. conica (agg.) is difficult for determination. Taxonomy described by different authors differs widely. I keep with Boertmann (Ref.7). Species H. acutoconica differs from members of H. conica agg. by absence of fast and deep blackening of fruitbodies during handling and in time. Pilei photographed didn’t blacken (or at least evidently much less than H. conica). H. acutoconica var. acutoconica has predominantly cylindrical, oblong and occasionally slightly constricted spores, which are. 5 – 6.5 microns wide (from 2-sterigmata basidia). Measured spores were evidently different – broadly elliptical, some elliptical and some subglobose. Their width was 7.4-7.9 microns (only 2-sterigmata basidia observed). Such spores correspond to Hygrocybe acutoconica var. konradii. According to Boertmann (2010) H. acutoconica var. acutoconica and H. acutoconica var. konradii are very similar and can be separated only by spore dimensions and shape. Pilei color og this find is unusual. It should ‘normally’ be yellow to reddish-yellow, however, Boertmann (2001) exceptionally allows also “… even entirely reddish”.

Two fruitbodies present; pilei diameter 35 and 32 mm (measured as is, not expanded), slightly viscid; stems 67 and 72 mm long, 6 and 7 mm in diameters, slightly viscid, with small diameter hollow central channel, fibrous; not bruising black when handling, only after long time becoming somewhat darker and duller; SP abundant, whitish-yellowish, oac 899.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5
results.location_name: Lower Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes:
Viscid cap, no notable scent.
These were growing on the wall of a waist-high ditch on the perimeter of the parking area. As I was taking these photos I noticed a horrid stench wafting in the light breeze. Further along the ditch, no more than 2m away, I located the origin of the smell; a discarded, stripped corpse of a deer along with Ziploc bags full of entrails. These bags had been torn open by scavengers and strewn all over. Reviewing these photos I wonder if that sludge seen around these mushrooms are contents of those bags.

results.notes:
I was extremely excited to find this candy-cap-like species, particularly once I realized it was growing in close proximity to what I believe to be L. xanthogalactus, whose white milk rapidly turned to sulfur yellow when exposed to air. These specimens, found growing in leaf litter in a mixed oak-conifer forest in the Sierra Foothills, had white milk that did not change color when exposed to air though no marked order. The stipes broke cleanly like chalk and were sometimes hollow. I noted no distinct odor, though understood that the maple-like smell of a true candy cap might not be prominent in a fresh specimen.

When I cut up and heated in water and sugar a handful of these mushrooms, I got only the faintest of mushroomy odors. Having worked with true candy caps about a year before, I expected the kitchen to smell of maple, and that clearly was not the case. Dejected, I dumped them.

I have offered in ID one candy cap lookalike whose geographic distribution does not fit this specimen, but not sure what it is. Suggestions welcome.

Colony characteristics not yet observed.

Confident ID appreciated – fungus colonised only seeds, not found on soil of any other organis debris on soil. Soil damp, calcareous.

Type: Filamentous synnematous fungus
Subtype: Conidiophores in fuzzy, brush-like heads (penicillus)
Colour on host: White synnematous column covered with blue-green spore mass at the upper half or more
Smell: Indistinct
Effects on Host: Indistinct
Length of synnemata: 3-6mm
Mould morphology (as it appears on host): Simple clavate or complex stag-horn shape composed of fused synnematous bodies

Fruiting bodies: Penicillia
Colour: Greyish green-cyan
General morphology: Asymmetric biverticillate
Penicillus diameter: 14.5 – 16 µm (mean: 15.3 µm)
Penicillus length: 26 – 29 µm (mean: 27.5 µm)
Branching of conidial heads: Two times (one branching elements, phialides)
Conidiophore colour: Hyaline, finely granulated (course) appearing greyish under LM
Conidiophore thickness: 5µm
Conidiophore length: 26 – 29 µm (mean: 27.5 µm)
Conidiophore ornamentation: Finely course by very minute punctations
Length of Metulae (=primary branches in this case): 10.2 – 12.3µm (mean 11µm)
Length of Phialides 11.8 – 12.8µm (mean 12µm)
Phialide shape: Elongated vase-shaped with a narrow but distinct collarette
Other morphological notes: Conidiophore very long, septate, straight or frequently sinusoidal, rising from meshwork of synnemata. Primary branches few, 2-3(4) appressed, sometimes curved.
Conidiospores
Conidia shape: Globose to subglobose (when in chains)
Conidia colour: Greyish-green

Conidiospore: ornamentation Smooth (barely distinguishible due small size)
Conidiospore length (range): 2.2 – 2.9 µm
Conidiospore width (range): 2.2 – 2.9 µm
Conidiospore size (mean): 2.5 × 2.5 µm
Conidiospore arrangement: Short straight chains, often with 4-6(-10) conidia, rarely longer.

Mycelium colour: White with a yellowish colour at the base
Hyphae septate: Yes

Presence of Ascii or Sclerotia: Not observed

Reactions
KOH: The synnemata becomes yellowish brown in KOH, somewhat more darker at the base.

results.notes: Hongo coprófilo, materia fecal de equino. Visto en Yopal – Cerro el venado. Pequeño 4 cm de altura. Pileo hemisférico 3cm diametro, color blanco y amarillento en el centro del pileo. En bosque muy húmedo pre montano (bmh-PM) se detectan alturas entre los 1000 – 2000 msnm. Segun el PMA 2007 presenta una precipitación media anual entre los 2000 – 4000 milímetros, una temperatura media anual entre los 18ºC – 24ºC grados centígrados, con vegetales representativos como Yarumo (Cecropia spp), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

results.notes: Encontrado en ecosistema de humedal Bogotá D.C. (Humedal La Conejera) bosque de Salix humboldtiana, Bocconia frutescens y Alnus acuminata. 4º 45´ latitud norte y 74º 6´ longitud oeste en la Sabana de Bogotá a una altura promedio de 2542 msnm. Humedad relativa del 80% (Chisacá, 2002) y una temperatura mínima que varían entre 0.9°C y – 4.2°C y temperatura promedio de 18-19°C (FHLC, 2002). El fungi se encontró creciendo en el suelo entre hojarasca principalmente de sauce lloron (Salix humboldtiana)

results.notes:
Microscopic features are
Spores 15-18 × 10-12.5 µ; ellipsoid to broadly ovoid; smooth; hyaline. Basidum 30- 50X 10-12.5 µ – with 4 long stigmata 10-12.5X 2-3.75 µ clavate to widly cylindrical,
Cheilocystidia narrowly to widely fusiform and subcylindric; 50-75 × 12-17.5 µ.
Pileipellis hymeniform subglobose-irregular to pyriform; pileocystidia frequent, thin-walled, hyaline, different size start from 25 –75 x12.5 µ.

results.notes: This polypore was found on an Oak tree about 18ft up. It was growing out of a damaged section of bark that exposed the interior of the tree trunk. Squirrels have been feeding on it as is evident by the scratchings and teeth marks on the surface. The night before I took these photos there was an amber colored liquid dripping out of many places on the bottom. There were wood roaches and palmetto bugs feeding off this fluid and maybe the mushroom as well. The spore print of this is brown but after 24 hours not much of a print, (this may be due to us being in drought conditions). Spongy around the perimeter, much more fibrous and dense near the stipe and mid-section.
